segment.source: Displays images in a collection, such as photos in an album or items in a product details page, one image at a time.
segment.target: Displays images in a collection, such as photos in an album or items in a product details page, one image at a time.

segment.source: Guidelines for flip view controls
segment.target: Guidelines for flip view controls

segment.source: Flip view
segment.target: Flip view

segment.source: Use a flip view for browsing images or other items in a collection, such as photos in an album or items in a product details page, one item at a time.
segment.target: Use a flip view for browsing images or other items in a collection, such as photos in an album or items in a product details page, one item at a time.

segment.source: For touch devices, swiping across an item moves through the collection.
segment.target: For touch devices, swiping across an item moves through the collection.

segment.source: For a mouse, navigation buttons appear on mouse hover.
segment.target: For a mouse, navigation buttons appear on mouse hover.

segment.source: For a keyboard, arrow keys move through the collection.
segment.target: For a keyboard, arrow keys move through the collection.

segment.source: Important APIs
segment.target: Important APIs

segment.source: FlipView class
segment.target: FlipView class

segment.source: ItemsSource
segment.target: ItemsSource

segment.source: ItemTemplate
segment.target: ItemTemplate

segment.source: Is this the right control?
segment.target: Is this the right control?

segment.source: Flip view is best for perusing images in small to medium collections (up to 25 or so items).
segment.target: Flip view is best for perusing images in small to medium collections (up to 25 or so items).

segment.source: Examples of such collections include items in a product details page or photos in a photo album.
segment.target: Examples of such collections include items in a product details page or photos in a photo album.

segment.source: Although we don't recommend flip view for most large collections, the control is common for viewing individual images in a photo album.
segment.target: Although we don't recommend flip view for most large collections, the control is common for viewing individual images in a photo album.

segment.source: Examples
segment.target: Examples

segment.source: Horizontal browsing, starting at the left-most item and flipping right, is the typical layout for a flip view.
segment.target: Horizontal browsing, starting at the left-most item and flipping right, is the typical layout for a flip view.

segment.source: This layout works well in either portrait or landscape orientation on all devices:
segment.target: This layout works well in either portrait or landscape orientation on all devices:

segment.source: Example of horizontal flip view layout
segment.target: Example of horizontal flip view layout

segment.source: A flip view can also be browsed vertically:
segment.target: A flip view can also be browsed vertically:

segment.source: Example of vertical flip view
segment.target: Example of vertical flip view

segment.source: Create a flip view
segment.target: Create a flip view

segment.source: FlipView is an ItemsControl, so it can contain a collection of items of any type.
segment.target: FlipView is an ItemsControl, so it can contain a collection of items of any type.

segment.source: To populate the view, add items to the Items collection, or set the ItemsSource property to a data source.
segment.target: To populate the view, add items to the Items collection, or set the ItemsSource property to a data source.

segment.source: By default, a data item is displayed in the flip view as the string representation of the data object it's bound to.
segment.target: By default, a data item is displayed in the flip view as the string representation of the data object it's bound to.

segment.source: To specify exactly how items in the flip view are displayed, you create a DataTemplate to define the layout of controls used to display an individual item.
segment.target: To specify exactly how items in the flip view are displayed, you create a DataTemplate to define the layout of controls used to display an individual item.

segment.source: The controls in the layout can be bound to properties of a data object, or have content defined inline.
segment.target: The controls in the layout can be bound to properties of a data object, or have content defined inline.

segment.source: You assign the DataTemplate to the ItemTemplate property of the FlipView.
segment.target: You assign the DataTemplate to the ItemTemplate property of the FlipView.

segment.source: Add items to the Items collection
segment.target: Add items to the Items collection

segment.source: You can add items to the Items collection using XAML or code.
segment.target: You can add items to the Items collection using XAML or code.

segment.source: You typically add items this way if you have a small number of items that don't change and are easily defined in XAML, or if you generate the items in code at run time.
segment.target: You typically add items this way if you have a small number of items that don't change and are easily defined in XAML, or if you generate the items in code at run time.

segment.source: Here's a flip view with items defined inline.
segment.target: Here's a flip view with items defined inline.

segment.source: When you add items to a flip view they are automatically placed in a FlipViewItem container.
segment.target: When you add items to a flip view they are automatically placed in a FlipViewItem container.

segment.source: To change how an item is displayed you can apply a style to the item container by setting the ItemContainerStyle property.
segment.target: To change how an item is displayed you can apply a style to the item container by setting the ItemContainerStyle property.

segment.source: When you define the items in XAML, they are automatically added to the Items collection.
segment.target: When you define the items in XAML, they are automatically added to the Items collection.

segment.source: Set the items source
segment.target: Set the items source

segment.source: You typically use a flip view to display data from a source such as a database or the Internet.
segment.target: You typically use a flip view to display data from a source such as a database or the Internet.

segment.source: To populate a flip view from a data source, you set its ItemsSource property to a collection of data items.
segment.target: To populate a flip view from a data source, you set its ItemsSource property to a collection of data items.

segment.source: Here, the flip view's ItemsSource is set in code directly to an instance of a collection.
segment.target: Here, the flip view's ItemsSource is set in code directly to an instance of a collection.

segment.source: You can also bind the ItemsSource property to a collection in XAML.
segment.target: You can also bind the ItemsSource property to a collection in XAML.

segment.source: For more info, see Data binding with XAML.
segment.target: For more info, see Data binding with XAML.

segment.source: Here, the ItemsSource is bound to a CollectionViewSource named .
segment.target: Here, the ItemsSource is bound to a CollectionViewSource named .

segment.source: NoteYou can populate a flip view either by adding items to its Items collection, or by setting its ItemsSource property, but you can't use both ways at the same time.
segment.target: NoteYou can populate a flip view either by adding items to its Items collection, or by setting its ItemsSource property, but you can't use both ways at the same time.

segment.source: If you set the ItemsSource property and you add an item in XAML, the added item is ignored.
segment.target: If you set the ItemsSource property and you add an item in XAML, the added item is ignored.

segment.source: If you set the ItemsSource property and you add an item to the Items collection in code, an exception is thrown.
segment.target: If you set the ItemsSource property and you add an item to the Items collection in code, an exception is thrown.

segment.source: Specify the look of the items
segment.target: Specify the look of the items

segment.source: By default, a data item is displayed in the flip view as the string representation of the data object it's bound to.
segment.target: By default, a data item is displayed in the flip view as the string representation of the data object it's bound to.

segment.source: You typically want to show a more rich presentation of your data.
segment.target: You typically want to show a more rich presentation of your data.

segment.source: To specify exactly how items in the flip view are displayed, you create a DataTemplate.
segment.target: To specify exactly how items in the flip view are displayed, you create a DataTemplate.

segment.source: The XAML in the DataTemplate defines the layout and appearance of controls used to display an individual item.
segment.target: The XAML in the DataTemplate defines the layout and appearance of controls used to display an individual item.

segment.source: The controls in the layout can be bound to properties of a data object, or have content defined inline.
segment.target: The controls in the layout can be bound to properties of a data object, or have content defined inline.

segment.source: The DataTemplate is assigned to the ItemTemplate property of the FlipView control.
segment.target: The DataTemplate is assigned to the ItemTemplate property of the FlipView control.

segment.source: In this example, the ItemTemplate of a FlipView is defined inline.
segment.target: In this example, the ItemTemplate of a FlipView is defined inline.

segment.source: An overlay is added to the image to display the image name.
segment.target: An overlay is added to the image to display the image name.

segment.source: Here's what the layout defined by the data template looks like.
segment.target: Here's what the layout defined by the data template looks like.

segment.source: Flip view data template.
segment.target: Flip view data template.

segment.source: Set the orientation of the flip view
segment.target: Set the orientation of the flip view

segment.source: By default, the flip view flips horizontally.
segment.target: By default, the flip view flips horizontally.

segment.source: To make the it flip vertically, use a stack panel with a vertical orientation as the flip view's ItemsPanel.
segment.target: To make the it flip vertically, use a stack panel with a vertical orientation as the flip view's ItemsPanel.

segment.source: This example shows how to use a stack panel with a vertical orientation as the ItemsPanel of a FlipView.
segment.target: This example shows how to use a stack panel with a vertical orientation as the ItemsPanel of a FlipView.

segment.source: Here's what the flip view looks like with a vertical orientation.
segment.target: Here's what the flip view looks like with a vertical orientation.

segment.source: Example of vertical flip view
segment.target: Example of vertical flip view

segment.source: Adding a context indicator
segment.target: Adding a context indicator

segment.source: A context indicator in a flip view provides a useful point of reference.
segment.target: A context indicator in a flip view provides a useful point of reference.

segment.source: The dots in a standard context indicator aren't interactive.
segment.target: The dots in a standard context indicator aren't interactive.

segment.source: As seen in this example, the best placement is usually centered and below the gallery:
segment.target: As seen in this example, the best placement is usually centered and below the gallery:

segment.source: Example of a page indicator
segment.target: Example of a page indicator

segment.source: For larger collections (10-25 items), consider using an indicator that provides more context, such as a film strip of thumbnails.
segment.target: For larger collections (10-25 items), consider using an indicator that provides more context, such as a film strip of thumbnails.

segment.source: Unlike a context indicator that uses simple dots, each thumbnail in the film strip shows a small version of the corresponding image and should be selectable:
segment.target: Unlike a context indicator that uses simple dots, each thumbnail in the film strip shows a small version of the corresponding image and should be selectable:

segment.source: Example of context indicator
segment.target: Example of context indicator

segment.source: Recommendations
segment.target: Recommendations

segment.source: Flip views work best for collections of up to 25 or so items.
segment.target: Flip views work best for collections of up to 25 or so items.

segment.source: Avoid using a flip view control for larger collections, as the repetitive motion of flipping through each item can be tedious.
segment.target: Avoid using a flip view control for larger collections, as the repetitive motion of flipping through each item can be tedious.

segment.source: An exception would be for photo albums, which often have hundreds or thousands of images.
segment.target: An exception would be for photo albums, which often have hundreds or thousands of images.

segment.source: Photo albums almost always switch to a flip view once a photo has been selected in the grid view layout.
segment.target: Photo albums almost always switch to a flip view once a photo has been selected in the grid view layout.

segment.source: For other large collections, consider a List view or grid view.
segment.target: For other large collections, consider a List view or grid view.

segment.source: For context indicators:
segment.target: For context indicators:

segment.source: The order of dots (or whichever visual marker you choose) works best when centered and below a horizontally-panning gallery.
segment.target: The order of dots (or whichever visual marker you choose) works best when centered and below a horizontally-panning gallery.

segment.source: If you want a context indicator in a vertically-panning gallery, it works best centered and to the right of the images.
segment.target: If you want a context indicator in a vertically-panning gallery, it works best centered and to the right of the images.

segment.source: The highlighted dot indicates the current item.
segment.target: The highlighted dot indicates the current item.

segment.source: Usually the highlighted dot is white and the other dots are gray.
segment.target: Usually the highlighted dot is white and the other dots are gray.

segment.source: The number of dots can vary, but don't have so many that the user might struggle to find his or her place - 10 dots is usually the maximum number to show.
segment.target: The number of dots can vary, but don't have so many that the user might struggle to find his or her place - 10 dots is usually the maximum number to show.

segment.source: Globalization and localization checklist
segment.target: Globalization and localization checklist

segment.source: Bi-directional considerations
segment.target: Bi-directional considerations

segment.source: Use standard mirroring for RTL languages.
segment.target: Use standard mirroring for RTL languages.

segment.source: The back and forward controls should be based on the language's direction, so for RTL languages, the right button should navigate backwards and the left button should navigate forward.
segment.target: The back and forward controls should be based on the language's direction, so for RTL languages, the right button should navigate backwards and the left button should navigate forward.
